column1: The universe can be viewed as having a hierarchical structure. At the largest scales
column2: the fundamental component of assembly is the galaxy. Galaxies are organized into groups and clusters
column4: that are strung along great filaments between nearly empty voids
column5: forming a web that spans the observable universe.Galaxies have a variety of morphologies
column8: depending on their formation and evolutionary histories
column10: which may lead to a merger.Disc galaxies encompass lenticular and spiral galaxies with features
column11: such as spiral arms and a distinct halo. At the core
column12: most galaxies have a supermassive black hole
column13: which may result in an active galactic nucleus. Galaxies can also have satellites in the form of dwarf galaxies and globular clusters.The constituents of a galaxy are formed out of gaseous matter that assembles through gravitational self-attraction in a hierarchical manner. At this level
column14: the resulting fundamental components are the stars
column15: which are typically assembled in clusters from the various condensing nebulae.
